text: In a hybrid grid maintenance in government where deliverables are nearly accepted and a formal close review is scheduled, what should the project manager do to determine criteria to successfully close the project or phase?

options.label: define acceptance and exit criteria with stakeholders
close when the calendar date arrives regardless of readiness
skip formal criteria to stay flexible
rely on budget exhaustion as the only signal

explanation: Option a is correct because clear criteria guide closure readiness. Option b is incorrect because date alone may not meet criteria. Option c is incorrect because lack of criteria invites disputes. Option d is incorrect because budget status is not sufficient for closure.

text: Given a predictive policy deployment in software where training is partially complete and support teams need readiness checks, which action best supports determine criteria to successfully close the project or phase?

options.label: avoid involving stakeholders in defining completion
verify deliverables and documentation required for closure
ignore operational readiness when setting criteria
close when the calendar date arrives regardless of readiness

explanation: Option b is correct because criteria must cover outputs. Option a is incorrect because stakeholder acceptance is essential. Option c is incorrect because operations readiness is critical for closure. Option d is incorrect because date alone may not meet criteria.

text: While facing a outsourced learning platform in software where deliverables are nearly accepted and resource releases are planned, what is the most effective next step to determine criteria to successfully close the project or phase?

options.label: skip formal criteria to stay flexible
rely on budget exhaustion as the only signal
confirm financial and contract closure needs
avoid involving stakeholders in defining completion

explanation: Option c is correct because closure includes commercial elements. Option a is incorrect because lack of criteria invites disputes. Option b is incorrect because budget status is not sufficient for closure. Option d is incorrect because stakeholder acceptance is essential.

text: For a hybrid learning platform in construction where deliverables are nearly accepted and a formal close review is scheduled, what should the project manager do first to determine criteria to successfully close the project or phase?

options.label: ignore operational readiness when setting criteria
close when the calendar date arrives regardless of readiness
skip formal criteria to stay flexible
align criteria with governance and compliance

explanation: Option d is correct because governance sets closure standards. Option a is incorrect because operations readiness is critical for closure. Option b is incorrect because date alone may not meet criteria. Option c is incorrect because lack of criteria invites disputes.

text: In a hybrid product release in government where deliverables are nearly accepted and lessons learned must be captured, what should the project manager do to determine criteria to successfully close the project or phase?

options.label: communicate criteria early to all parties
rely on budget exhaustion as the only signal
avoid involving stakeholders in defining completion
ignore operational readiness when setting criteria

explanation: Option a is correct because visibility ensures preparation. Option b is incorrect because budget status is not sufficient for closure. Option c is incorrect because stakeholder acceptance is essential. Option d is incorrect because operations readiness is critical for closure.
